) shows the changes of the PL intensities of
phosphor at the emission peaks of 495 nm.
3.4. Morphology and CIE Chromaticity Coordinates of Bi
The quality of a phosphor powder is related not only to its chemical and phase purity but also
to the particle size and morphology [38]. Figure 4(a,b) are the FESEM morphologies of BiOCl and
samples, respectively. It can be seen that all these particles were in irregular
oblate spheres. The particle size was uniform and about 1–3 μm. The average particle size was close
to the optimal shape and size, which also had a positive impact on the luminescence performance.
As shown in Figure 4(c), the CIE chromaticity coordinates are presented to evaluate the color
excitation at 453 nm, the CIE coordinates of Bi
phosphor were calculated and dropped in
the green-yellow light region. The CIE coordinate point gradually shifted to the yellow light region
concentration. The PL quantum yields of the selected samples Bi
0.0025, 0.005, 0.0075, 0.01) under excitation at 453 nm were measured to be 35.4%, 30.8%, 24.9%, and
25.1%. Although the quantum efficiency values of BiOCl:Pr
phosphors were still lower than those
of commercial phosphors, they could be increased through purification, surface coating treatment,
or doping with other rare earth elements (e.g., Sm, Y, Li, and Bi) prior to further commercial
applications [39–41]. Furthermore, the two insets show the photographs of the fabricated w-LED
device before (left) and after (right) switching on the power. It can be seen that the fabricated
w-LED device could emit white light, combining with a blue light chip and some red phosphors.
All these results indicate the BiOCl:Pr
phosphors have good thermal stability, green-yellow
spectrum, and light luminescence efficiency, which indicates that BiOCl:Pr
green-yellow phosphor material and widely used in blue-light-based w-LEDs.
) shows the changes of the PL intensities
phosphor at the emission peaks of 495 nm.
3.4. Morphology and CIE Chromaticity Coordinates of Bi
The quality of a phosphor powder is related not only to its chemical and phase purity but also
to the particle size and morphology [
a,b are the FESEM morphologies of BiOCl and
samples, respectively. It can be seen that all these particles were in irregular
oblate spheres. The particle size was uniformand about 1–3
m. The average particle size was close to
the optimal shape and size, which also had a positive impact on the luminescence performance.
The insets show the photographs of the fabricated white-light-emitting diode (w-LED) device before
(left) and after (right) switching on the power.
phosphors were synthesized by a solid-state reaction method.
Under excitation at 453 nm, the BiOCl:Pr
phosphors exhibited a green-yellow light with four
emission peaks at 495, 535, 624, and 655 nm. These emission peaks are attributed to the
was obtained with a CIE coordinate (0.2847, 0.4439). In addition, the Bi
could also maintain a good thermal stability at high temperature. The intensity of emission peaks at
150 °C was about 78% of the initial intensity at room temperature. The quantum yield was measured
to be 24.9%. The results show that BiOCl:Pr
which may be suitable for application in blue-light-based w-LEDs.
